Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Flux Thin Film Nanocomposite Reverse Osmosis Membrane
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to mitigate the global freshwater crisis. Water supplies are under stress in many areas of the world. Securing a supply of fresh water to meet the needs of population growth and increased industrialization is a global challenge. The proposed technology in this SBIR project will offer an opportunity to produce large scale high performance RO membranes in a continuous format at low cost to facilitate lower cost water purification. Phase I of this program will demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed approach in a batch format and lay a solid foundation for large through-put continuous production. This program will also enable further scientific/technological understanding on zeolite nanocrystal synthesis, self-assembly based on static charge interaction and chemical reaction.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to develop a commercially viable spray based layer by layer (LbL) deposition approach to fabricate thin film nanocomposite (TFN) RO membranes with more process control. Current RO purification systems require a high driving pressure mainly because of low water flux and fouling of the membranes. The proposed approach allows fabrication of highly cross-linked polyamide (PA) nanocomposite membranes with nanometer control over the film thickness, minimal roughness, uniform nanoparticle distribution, and defined local chemical and polymer composition. Compared with traditional reverse osmosis PA membranes, significant benefits can be expected from the proposed membrane including 2 to 3 times improvement in water flux, lower driving pressure, and less fouling and ease for cleaning. This SBIR program aims to develop a spray assembly technology to fabricate highly cross-linked TFN membranes on a porous support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report

Procuring clean and potable water from high salinity sources is paramount to address the growing challenge of global water scarcity. Desalination, a technological process that in simple terms removes salts and minerals from seawater, can play a pivotal role in the future water management strategy. Current desalination technology leans heavily on the ability of the synthetic reverse osmosis (RO) membranes to selectively let water permeate through its structure while rejecting unwanted constituents using a barrier. This exclusive specificity is provided by a thin (~200 nm) crosslinked polyamide film allocated at the forefront of thin film composite membranes (TFC), the state of the art RO membrane in the industry. 

The overall goal of this project was to fabricate a thin film nanocomposite (TFN) RO membrane capable of providing high water flux while maintaining the selectivity desired by the industry. In this project, we adopted a completely novel fabrication route to form crosslinked polyamide using a self-assembly deposition method with molecular precision. This polyamide was grown on commercial substrate with a nanostructured top layer which has unique ability to enhance water transport.  Formation of the crosslinked polyamide film using layer-by-layer (LbL) fabrication assembly was studied under different experimental conditions. Systematic experiments gave us better understanding to identify the appropriate formulation of the chemical reaction, optimized process conditions and post-polymerization treatments that can improve overall membrane performance.

We found that this LbL fabrication method can easily be rendered into large scale manufacturing for both regular and surface modified supports. Polyamides formulated using this method displayed very smooth surface morphology, uniform chemical composition, and thinner film formation compared to the conventional membranes. Permeate flux of the membranes were increased multiple times by modifying surface of the support and reducing the polyamide film thickness.

In conclusion, this Phase I SBIR project successfully demonstrated the technical feasibility of our approach to fabricate high flux TFN membranes for water purification by using novel proprietary method. Uniqueness and simple application of this fabrication process is easily compatible with large scale manufacturing and development of these high flux membranes could ease some of the stresses in current water management system caused by population growth, industrialization, and climate change. 

 


Last Modified: 02/09/2018
Modified by: Qingwu Wang
